sn35.108:1.1: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
sn35.108:2.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn35.108:3.1: “When there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye and insisting on the eye, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’. …
sn35.108:3.3: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind and insisting on the mind, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.
sn35.108:3.5: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.108:5.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.108:7.1: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
sn35.108:12.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.108:14.1: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
sn35.108:16.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn35.108:16.2: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
sn35.108:16.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
